subject: Add multi-host postcode support
commitMessage:
Add multi-host postcode support

These changes add the multiple host postcode implementation. In addition to the
LPC snoop the postcode can be read via D-Bus interface.The same is displayed
in seven segment display thorough GPIO lines.

The design can be refered at
   https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/35065

Tested:

 Verified in Facebook Tiogapass & Yosemitev2.

1.The postcode displayed in the seven segment corresponding to the
  host position selected in the frontpanel of Facebook yosemitev2(4 host).

2.The postcode history is verified in the respective host directory
     "/var/lib/phosphor-post-code-manager/hostX(1,2,3,4)".

Signed-off-by: Manikandan Elumalai <manikandan.hcl.ers.epl@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I5ad882e107131ee9591f3cc4917287c3ab103e1a

Patch Set 6:

(25 comments)

Abandoned

Alternate Gerrit link for this patch. Please refer(https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-host-postd/+/45805)
Please rebase this commit onto https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-host-postd/+/31051 so we can avoid keeping the autotools portions up to date.
This patch is already merged with master.
You should also add a `rules::argN(0, InterfaceName)` where InterfaceName is the interface which you are expecting to emit this PropertiesChanged signal.
Unresolved.
Done
This assumes that 'raw' only shows up once in the path which is a bad assumption.  I would suggest using std::filesystem methods to obtain the last path segment.
Done
Done
Why '+ 3'?  This is a magic number.  Use constants.
Done. To parse the host num from the object.
What is this { } scope for?
Removed.

It seems odd to me that you've defined the variant as uint64_t and passing it, but the function takes a uint8_t.  This is silently truncating.  Why not just read from dbus as a uint8_t?  What is the type sent along dbus?  Do you need error reporting if the postcode > 255?
The Value reading from dbus is Variant type. Phosphor-dbus-iterfaces has type as uint16_t.
Do the maintainers want cout/cerr logging or phosphor-logging?
Done
Why is this interesting to log?
Done

Please don't use rc-style returns in C++ code.  Throw an exception if something went bad that someone can usefully recover from.  If nobody ever cares, then just return void and eat/log the error inside this function.

This comment goes for all your functions here.
Why this type?
Done
Done
Should this be 'extern'?  You're defining a global for some reason in a header file.
moved to main.cpp

Do you really want to read the property or should you be listening to signals from it also/instead?  You could just cache the signal value.

Also, how do you handle if the selector changes position?  Shouldn't you update the display after the selector changes position?  (again, you need to listen to a signal)
Modified this function and created aysnc_get function to get the properties.
This seems very wrong to create a static asio context inside a function and then operate on it synchronously.
Done
Should you be using sdbusplus::asio::getProperty?
Done

This will never be true for a synchronous method call.

You might get an exception from line 93 though.
Done
I don't think 'int' is the right type on this based on the proposed dbus interfaces.
Done
Why did you include gpiod.hpp (the C++ file) and then use C APIs?  I suggest using the C++ APIs directly.
Done
The C++ APIs allow you to create a 'line_bulk' object to hold all the GPIOs associated with post code and set them all in one go.
Done
Isn't there a kernel module that turns a set of GPIOs into a 7seg display?  Isn't that what '7seg.cpp' is using?  Is there a reason we're not using that?

The kernel community is not accepting the below patch. So, we are not using 7seg.cpp
https://lore.kernel.org/patchwork/cover/743571/
Isn't there some place that we need to do a translation from 'status' into a 7seg display?  Simple bit-shifting doesn't seem to cover it to me.
Translation is not needed. Debug card displays the one byte data in the 7seg display by default.
My suggestion is that these are two different compile-time options.  I don't think any machine will be using both options, would they?
Done

Can you integrate this code into 'main'?  Right now we've got this main function that handles creating dbus constructs for lpcsnoop and this separate function for your new ipmisnoop.  They should be mostly common.
Suggest this is optional based on compile flag (if even needed anymore based on recommendation of using 7seg kernel module).
Done
It isn't obvious why your commit needs these options.  If they're unrelated to your commit, please put into a separate commit.
Done
Why would any of these header files be installed??  We're not providing a library here.
Done

Why 3?  Please document.

Why aren't you looking for 'raw' anymore?
Please don't mix C/C++.
